title: Fikayo Tomori talks England call-up, Frank Lampard's Chelsea plan, and breaking Diego Costa's nose
text:
Fikayo Tomori was still at school when he broke Diego Costa’s nose on the Chelsea training pitch and the club’s latest Academy graduate to win an England call-up has since proved he is a fast learner.

Chelsea fans would have barely heard of the Tomori, then aged 18, when they picked up the newspapers in February 2016 to find out Costa had been forced to make a dash to Milan to be fitted for a protective mask so he could face Newcastle United.​

Fortunately for Tomori, Costa scored after just five minutes in a 5-1 thrashing and the incident was quickly forgotten about at Chelsea – even if he had become infamous at his school.​

“I was actually still in school and I didn’t know I had done it in training,” said Tomori, who had been invited to train with the first-team squad by interim manager Guus Hiddink. “It was an accident, we both went up for a header and I had to flick the ball backwards and he tried to score. He headed the back of my head and he broke his nose. I didn’t know I had done it until the next day when it was all over the papers. I was getting a lot of messages with people thinking I had meant to do it! It was mostly light-hearted, a lot of banter. I got back to school and people were asking about it. I was in year 10 or 11 and my mates had all seen it.”​

Given Costa’s infamous temper, Tomori might have been watching his back when the pair returned to the training pitch, but he added: “It was all right. He didn’t kick me in training after that.”​
